source:
public bike share (PBS) scheme ، It is the one of the services that allows the shared use of bicycles for a low price or for free ، One of the advantages of this system is that it allows people to borrow a bike from one dock and return it to another dock ، The Docks are equipped with a system to lock and on lock the bicycles by computer control ، The person enters the payment method ، Then the computer opens the lock to return the bike .

In this project we will perform an exploratory analysis of data provided by Ford GoBike, a bike-share system provider.

# Wrangling


Ford GoBike It is a local bike-sharing system in San Francisco , In this dataset we have information about , individual bicycle rides made in a bike-sharing system and, the dataset which will be explored from june 2017 to december 2018.

import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sb
from pandas import Series, DataFrame
import requests
import os
import csv 
%matplotlib inline

# in this step we loading 2017 data
data_2017 = pd.read_csv('2017_fordgobike.csv')

source: # in this step we get general info 2018 data
# in this step we Get overview 2018 Data

# collecting monthly dataframes to one dataset
list18 = []
for i in range(12):
    month = '%02d' % (i+1)
    file = '2018_' + month + '_fordgobike.zip'
    if os.path.exists(file):
        list18.append(dictionary18[month])
        
data_2018 = pd.concat(list18, ignore_index = True)

#### converting non-null values 'start_station_id' and 'end_station_id' to strings and

#  in this step we converting non-null values to strings 
df1718['start_station_id'] =df1718['start_station_id'].where(df1718['start_station_id'].isnull(), df1718['start_station_id'].map(lambda x: '{:.0f}'.format(x)).astype(str))
df1718['end_station_id'] = df1718['end_station_id'].where(df1718['end_station_id'].isnull(), df1718['end_station_id'].map(lambda x: '{:.0f}'.format(x)).astype(str))
# in this step we converting "bike_id" from int to string

source: We can estimate a simple age by way of his year of birth and time of departure. Represent null ages due to missing birth year by 0.

df1718.loc[df1718['member_birth_year'] == 0, 'Age'] = 0
df1718.loc[df1718['member_birth_year'] > 0, 'Age'] = df1718['start_time'].dt.year - df1718['member_birth_year']
df1718['Age'] = df1718['Age'].astype(int)

source:
## What is the structure of your dataset?

In the dataset we have data that contains (2383421 rows, 18 columns) ، Each row represents a bike ride / rental in the period of June 2017 to December 2018. ، The data type in the dataset is different ، The type is "the String type" contains  Station names, 'user_type', 'member_gender' . 
And we have "integer data" And it contains  "member_birth_year" and the trips duration and 'start_time' and 'end_time'.
## What is/are the main feature(s) of interest in your dataset?

Total number of rounds and duration 

Duration per trip.

What kind of users are using the FordGoBike service more and less.
## What features in the dataset do you think will help support your investigation into your feature(s) of interest?
Some information for data year of birth and gender, can give us insight into the number of users.

text/plain:
Male     74.16
Female   24.33

source: #### The result is that males make more trips

text/plain:

Name: user_type, dtype: float64

source:
plt.figure(figsize=[10, 10])
(df1718_copy.user_type.value_counts(sort=True, normalize=True)*100).plot.bar(color = sb.color_palette()[2])
plt.title("the Rides per user type")
plt.ylabel("the sum rides")
plt.xlabel("the user type");
#### th subscribers type  have most rides

plt.figure(figsize=[10, 10])
df1718_age = df1718_copy.query('Age > 0')
bins = np.arange(0, df1718_age['Age'].max()+2, 2)
plt.hist(data = df1718_age, x = 'Age', bins = bins)
plt.title("The Age distribution")
plt.xlabel('the Age')
plt.ylabel('the Count The Trips');

Sduration = Skeep_male_female.groupby(['member_gender', 'Gage'])['duration_sec'].agg('sum')
Sduration = Sduration 
Sduration = Sduration.reset_index(name = 'duration_min')
Sduration = Sduration.pivot(index = 'Gage', columns = 'member_gender', values = 'duration_min')
Sduration.sample(3)

plt.figure(figsize = [15, 15])
plt.subplot(2, 2, 1)
sb.heatmap(Srides/1000, annot = True, fmt =  '.0f',  cmap = 'PuRd')
plt.title("count of Rides per Gender and Age Group")
plt.ylabel("The Age Group")
plt.xlabel("The Gender")
plt.yticks(rotation=360);

plt.figure(figsize = [15, 15])
plt.subplot(2, 2, 2)
sb.heatmap(Sduration/60/60/1000, annot = True, fmt =  '.2f',  cmap = 'PuRd', yticklabels=False)
plt.title("Sum of all Rides Duration per Gender and Age Group ")
plt.ylabel("the Age Group")
plt.xlabel("the Gender");

plt.figure(figsize = [15, 15])
plt.subplot(2, 2, 3)
sb.heatmap(SDS/60, annot = True, fmt =  '.2f',  cmap = 'PuRd');
plt.title("Average Ride Duration per Gender and Age Group ")
plt.ylabel("the Age Group")
plt.xlabel("the Gender")
plt.yticks(rotation=360);
